response.answer_text: This question is ambiguous as written. “Is technology innovation flattening” could mean Is the growth of technology flattening the rich/poor divide around the world (I thought it meant this but that may not be your intention)Is the acceleration of technology slowingIs technology growth flattening economics because it’s both deflationary and exponentialQuestion 1: In some ways, if we look at the cost for a “good” cellphone, or a computer, or a flatscreen TV we can see that the deflationary price/quality of these items flattens out data access for much more of the population of the world. Over time data becomes cheaper. I believe we’ll see this with power as Solar PV and batteries follow Swanson’s Law. In this sense, technological innovation is flattening the rich/poor divide (though in other aspects like rents, utilities, healthcare, access to travel, it is not) Question 2: No, technological progress is accelerating. Most of this is invisible because we’re going through several big changes (from x86 to ARM processors, from standard RAM to next-gen RAM, from server rooms to cloud computing). You can only see the expensive new technology as expensive new devices, but like the $17,000 flatscreen in 1997, eventually, they’ll come down in price and become commodified (the same TV would cost less than 1/50 of its 1997 price). Question 3: Yes technological innovation is flattening economics, as you can see in my answer to question 2, along with accelerating automation technology innovation is flattening economics.

If it is not, it should be… The rapid technological changes (e.g., the introduction of the Internet) often cause social changes.
